snippet: Looking at this year's best-picture nominees from a rabbi's point of view.
abstract: Looking at this year's best-picture nominees from a rabbi's point of view.
lead_paragraph: Of the Academy's nearly 6,000 members, most work primarily in film, but not all of them. One gives her title as Reverend Mother. Another is listed as Pastor. And then there's Marvin Hier, a member better known as the rabbi who founded the Weisenthal Center in Los Angeles. Through Moriah Films, he has produced many documentaries, including "Genocide," which won an Oscar and the rabbi's admittance to the Academy. On his ballot this year, he sees "travails, triumphs, noble struggles and sheer folly in the unusually rich stew of morality tales that are this year's nine best picture nominees," the Bagger's colleague Michael Cieply writes. For the rabbi, "The Artist" recalls a passage in Psalms, and George Clooney's character in "The Descendants" is reminiscent of Job "but with all the complications of the 21st century." Read more »
